reasoning: Crucial because the paper’s trade-based optimism is highly sensitive to whether value-destroying threats are equilibrium behavior and how costly they are; resolving this would substantially shift views on whether to prioritize enabling moral trade vs prioritizing threat-prevention/robust institutions. Strong paper-specificity: the question directly targets the essay’s distinctive emphasis on moral trade being undermined by executed threats and the claim that even small fractions of threat-execution can dominate EV under many axiologies. Tractability is moderate: there are plausible research paths (formal game-theoretic modeling of commitment/threat equilibria, mechanism design, empirical/agent-based simulations, lab/field evidence from extortion/credible-commitment analogues), but mapping to post-AGI/high-stakes settings is hard and results will be model-sensitive. Clarity is decent but not perfect: key terms like “value-destroying,” “resource-intensive,” “commitment capabilities,” and the relevant equilibrium concept need operationalization; it also bundles prevalence + intensity + institutional design/stability + lock-in side-effects. Decision hook is explicit (rare/containable vs equilibrium/hard-to-prevent implies optimism vs pessimism and different priorities). Dead weight is low: the context mainly sharpens why the question matters and what flips on the answer.
title: Prevalence and containability of value-destroying threats in commitment-capable multiagent equilibria
